utilities
Class Logger

java.lang.Object
  utilities.Logger
Direct Known Subclasses:
ConsoleLogger, DummyLogger, MultiFileLogger, MultiLogger, SingleFileLogger
public abstract class Logger
extends java.lang.Object

Logging base class. Provides methods useful for simple event-logging. Every logger must have an unique name because it's used for identifying the logger.
Per default, a logger is disabled it is when created, so logging must be explicitly enabled.

Author:
Oliver Schwahn

Field Detail

logName

protected java.lang.String logName
This logger's name. This name should be added as source to every logged event.

loggingEnabled

protected boolean loggingEnabled
Indicates whether logging functionality is enabled or disabled.

curLogLevel

protected LogLevel curLogLevel
All events of this LogLevel or above will be logged. All events below this LogLevel won't be logged.

Constructor Detail

Logger

public Logger(java.lang.String name)
Constructor. A Logger can only be created if a name is given.
Per default, logging is disabled and log level is set to Debug.

Parameters:
name - This logger's name.

Logger

public Logger(java.lang.String name,
              LogLevel curLevel)
Extended constructor. A Logger can only be created if a name is given.
Per default, logging is disabled.

Parameters:
name - This logger's name.
curLevel - This logger's minimum LogLevel.
Method Detail

enableLogging

public final void enableLogging()
Enables logging functionality. If logging is disabled, all logged events disappear in the great wide nirvana.

See Also:
disableLogging(), setLoggingStatus(boolean)

disableLogging

public final void disableLogging()
Disables logging functionality. If logging is disabled, all logged events disappear in the great wide nirvana.

See Also:
enableLogging(), setLoggingStatus(boolean)

setLoggingStatus

public void setLoggingStatus(boolean enabled)
Enables or disables logging functionality. If logging is disabled, all logged events disappear in the great wide nirvana.

Parameters:
enabled - If true, logging gets enabled, otherwise logging gets disabled.
See Also:
enableLogging(), disableLogging()

isEnabled

public final boolean isEnabled()
Checks whether logging functionality is enabled.

Returns:
True, if logging is enabled, false otherwise.

getTimestamp

protected static java.lang.String getTimestamp()
Gets the current timestamp. Current system time is formatted as "DD.MM.YYYY hh:mm:ss".

Returns:
Current timestamp as string.

hasRightLevel

protected boolean hasRightLevel(LogLevel level)
Checks whether an event with a given LogLevel must be logged.

Parameters:
level - LogLevel to check.
Returns:
True if event must be logged, false otherwise.

changeName

protected void changeName(java.lang.String newName)
Internal helper for changing the logger's name. Optimally this is never used, because of problems that might appear by changing the name. So use with care!

Parameters:
newName - Logger's new name.

getLoggerName

public final java.lang.String getLoggerName()
Gets this Logger's name.

Returns:
Logger's name.

setLogLevel

public void setLogLevel(LogLevel level)
Changes the current LogLevel to the given one.

Parameters:
level - Logger's new LogLevel.

Logs a given message with LogLevel Debug. A timestamp is added automatically.

Parameters:
msg - Message to be logged.

public void log(LogLevel level,
                java.lang.String msg)

log

public abstract void log(LogLevel level,
                         java.lang.String timestamp,
                         java.lang.String msg)
Logs a given message with a given LogLevel and a given timestamp.

Parameters:
level - LogLevel to by applied.
timestamp - Timestamp to be added.
msg - Message to be logged.
